 Simone by some chance did you happen to catch the multitude of protesters that gathered in Washington this week not once but twice in protest of this government takeover called health care?
 Did you happen to see coverage of the protests happening across the country this week at the offices of those in Congress against the health care bill?
 Did you happen to catch the news that Congress received over 100,000 calls an hour asking representatives to vote no on the bill?
 
 These folks are those you declare stupid and mock by calling them "teabaggers".
 
 But what the majority of people in this country define as stupid is anyone who would believe the words "Hello I'm from the government and am here to help you". They also define stupid as someone willing to circumvent the legal process to force compliance of a partisan agenda causing all citizens to give up freedoms in the process. 
 
 And the stupid of all stupid are those who listened to the president yesterday when he lamented over those in his party having to make a "tough" vote stating he has been in their shoes as he encouraged his party faithful to fall on their swords and the dumb Democrats listened and cheered their leader forgetting he (Obama) in his short political career voted "present" 128 times.

I agree Archangel. Once it becomes LAW it is very tough to undo the damage.
 
 What I do find hopeful is what the states are gearing up to do. The lawsuits are about to be filed. I believe there are close to 40 states involved. Congress may be able to make LAW over all the land but that LAW must be constitutional. Clearly, forced coverage is not and placing a burden on the states that they can not meet isn't either. And the process in which this bill is getting passed may also strengthen the cases.
 
 I don't think those folks who are in favor of this bill have any idea what the financial burden this boondoggle will be on the states that inevitably will mean higher state and local taxes compounded with the added taxes in this bill that will affect all of us.. I don't believe they have really thought through the idea of giving the IRS the power to police their health care. I don't think they realize how long it is going to take to see a doctor because of the shortage of doctors this bill is going to create. We have already heard from them and were warned that if this bill was to pass, many will retire early and others will close up their practice. Then there are those who are opting out not to see anymore Medicare and Medicaid patients because they can't afford to because the states are having a difficult time in reimbursing them. 
 
 It's a friggen mess.

 Great post and an accurate assessment of the situation. All one has to do is look at Massachussets to see how the budgetary estimates are nothing more than pipe dreams when compared to the reality just 4 years after being enacted. Even the CBO said their estimates were just that, based on the numbers they had to work with. 
 
 We can't lose sight of the fact that the government has never run a business successfully at a profit. It isn't designed to run businesses but to run beurocracies. It spends money, it doesn't earn money. We are being told to pay for a program for the next 4 years before it will actually become active, yet they think we are dumb enough to believe them when they say this is a cost neutral program as if it wont cost us anything in the long run. 
 
 It's the lies that get to me more than anything, but every single aspect of this healthcare bill is founded in lies and misinformation. But those on the left defend these lies as if their lives depend on it. I'm truly saddened by todays events; my America is polarized and at opposite ends of the spectrum. The vote is currently 174 Yea and 146 Nay, it is believed that the dems have the 216 votes needed to pass this sham of a bill. emoticon_cry
